awd_titl_txt: CAREER: NOVEL INTEGRATION OF FLUID DYNAMIC DESIGN INTO ELECTRIC MACHINES
awd_abstract_narration:
Energy efficiency and sustainable use of energy continue to be among nations' most pressing challenges as global energy demand steadily increases. In fact, global energy needs will continue to grow steadily into the future. Recent studies indicate that the world's primary energy demand is likely to grow more than 50% by 2030. Among global electric energy needs, compressor systems consume a substantial proportion.  The applications for compressors are very broad and useful for humanity from many perspectives. Compressors can be found in very small equipment such as sleep apnea machines, to kilo-Watt level micro-turbines for power generation and heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems, to mega-Watt level natural gas turbines of power plants. Another useful and sustainable application of compressors is for compressed air energy storage systems. Other applications include prime mover of electrical generation systems, aircraft jet engines, and high-speed propulsion systems. Among all compressor types, axial flow compressors have one of the highest efficiency, and most of the axial flow compressors require electric motors. Hence, there is a need to design electric motors that can run the axial flow compressors at high speed and efficiency at low cost. The motivation of this research aims to develop an advanced electric machine to replace older, inefficient compressor topologies with axial flow compressors, paving the way for more efficient and sustainable energy use. The research proposes a novel and transformative motor, by combining the rotor of the electric motor and airfoil of a compressor into one structure. This approach will reduce the weight, volume, and cost of the axial flow compressor systems and increase the efficiency compared to traditional separate motor and compressor designs. The CAREER project aims to disseminate the research results to university students via credit courses, practicing engineers via short courses, seminars, and tutorials, and the general public via demonstrations and open houses. The project will promote participation of women and under-represented minorities in undergraduate and graduate engineering education to advance equal participation and advance diversity via various workshops and STEM activities such as Camp Badger. 

The central hypothesis underlying this research effort is that if a rotor of electric machine is shaped as an airfoil, then there will be a conversion of mechanical torque from the rotor to kinetic energy in the fluid, because the rotor will serve as an airfoil for the compressor and compress the gas.  Hence, this CAREER research proposes a novel electric machine where the rotor is shaped as an airfoil that achieves both motoring and compressor function.  This approach will achieve self-cooling of the rotor and stator due to inherent gas flow, reduction in the axial length of the compressor, simpler and more robust mechanical design due to reduced axial length, and simpler bearing design due to reduced axial length.   The research aims to develop a unified theory of electric machines and turbo machinery to integrate the torque production and fluid dynamics. Multi-physics simulations will be performed to analyze the electromechanical, thermal, structural, and fluid dynamic attributes.  Performance characteristics will be researched and benefits of the novel integrated rotor-airfoil design will be quantified and compared with traditional separate motor and compressor designs.  Finally, a proof-of-concept prototype will be built and tested to validate the design, analytical and simulation results. This transformational research aims to achieve lower weight, volume, and cost, higher efficiency, and higher reliability of next generation high-speed compressor systems. The proposed concept is applicable to and will be investigated for turbines and fans.

por.por_cntn:
This project was carried out by a University of Wisconsin-Madison research team with support from an NSF CAREER Award. This research pursued an original, innovative concept for designing an integrated electric motor and a compressor that combines these two key functions into a single housing that simultaneously produces torque and fluid flow. The project goals were to reduce the overall unit's weight and volume and increase its efficiency using the combined motor-driven compressor design.

A critical research consideration was shaping the motor's spinning rotor poles as compressor blade airfoils to generate the desired airflow as the rotor rotates. Using simulation, both the rotor pole's ability to provide torque production and airflow were thoroughly analyzed. Specifically, the torque production was analyzed using electromagnetic theory and finite element tools to optimize the motor efficiency. Concurrently, the rotor compressor blades' fluid dynamics were analyzed using analytical calculations based on vector diagrams and more complex computational fluid dynamics simulations. Ultimately, a sizing equation for the electromagnetic design of the integrated motor-compressor was developed using a high-performance flux-switching permanent magnet motor topology. Careful attention was devoted to analyzing the effect of shaping the rotor poles into compressor blades on the motor's performance. The scalability of the integrated motor-compressor to higher power levels was also investigated.

These powerful analytical tools were used to predict valuable reductions in the unit's weight, volume, and active component numbers that were achievable by the new integrated motor-compressor compared to the traditional motor-driven compressors consisting of separately-housed motor and compressor units. The simulated airflow produced by the rotor blades provided effective self-cooling for the integrated motor. To take full advantage of the self-cooling feature, the size and placement of inlet and outlet openings on the machine housing were optimized to maximize the cooling of the motor's windings and stator surfaces.

A proof-of-concept machine was designed and built using the flux-switching permanent magnet motor topology. 3-D printing was used to manufacture the blade caps and the integrated motor-compressor housing. The motor torque production, pressure rise, and cooling performance of the proof-of-concept machine were evaluated by performing tests on the prototype unit. The proof-of-concept machine demonstrated its ability to achieve sufficient self-cooling when operating at its rated power operating point. The experimental results validated the integrated motor-compressor concept and its advantages. Overall efficiency, compactness, and anticipated reliability were improved when compared to the traditional motor compressor combination.

Several patent disclosures have been filed as a result of this research.

The research results were broadly disseminated in conferences, seminars, and short courses. The results were published in twenty papers and presented at ten conferences. They have also been presented to more than 1,000 engineers from the power electronics industry during the annual review meetings of the Wisconsin Electric Machine and Power Electronics Consortium (WEMPEC) at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. The motor-compressor concept was also incorporated into two annual short courses on electric motors offered by the university. More than 60 practicing engineers participate in these short courses each year.

To expand the research impact, the electric machines team participated in Wisconsin (WI) Idea STEM Fellows workshops. These workshops were part of an NSF-supported initiative, Portal to the Public Network. Using best practice models for online/in-person engagement, the team developed a Minimal Viable Prototype (MVP). More than 300 elementary, middle, and high school students, plus 12 teachers, participated online and in-person at Family Science Night, Camp Badger, and the Summer Science Camp Workshop. The students and teachers learned about new concepts in electrical engineering, such as electric vehicles, electric aircraft, and flying cars, as well as electrical engineering careers. Each student received a motor and generator kit plus an interactive video describing the kit assembly. The students worked on the kits both in-person at campus labs and during Zoom-hosted sessions. In both venues, the students and their teachers had extensive discussions with the research team members regarding both the motor kit and a wide range of electrical engineering topics.

This project created many rich engineering research and learning opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students in the Electrical and Computer Engineering Department and Mechanical Engineering Department at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. Four Ph.D. and two MS students plus several undergraduate students productively participated in the research. Hundreds of K-12 STEM students, their teachers, 1,000+ engineers, plus large numbers of research and conference paper readers have already learned about and benefited from this research, and these numbers are certain to grow in coming years. The support of the National Science Foundation was critical for enabling this research and is greatly appreciated.
